title: As a wizard (versus a Quidditch player), what was Harry Potter best at? - Quora

response.answer_text: What was Harry Potter the best at, not including Quidditch? I wouldn’t choose Quidditch to begin with. Maybe for Viktor Krum, because he became an international player while still a student. But Harry had many other talents. Harry thought quickly on his feet. That’s what I see him doing the best: doing well and beating the old masters at quick-thinking. Harry Potter doesn’t have lots to lose, given that he does not have a family to protect, so he throws caution to the wind when he must and he solves problems. Problems that no other student would even think about during a dull moment in class.  The Philosopher’s Stone? What other students gave a second thought to what Fluffy was guarding upstairs? Oh, yeah, they didn’t know a Fluffy existed. They were busy dreaming of their next snogging session or pondering the delicate flavors of pumpkin juice. And as a first year, Ron and Hermione came along for the ride because Harry dragged them into it. And then they discovered how much they loved helping Harry solving hidden mysteries. They were adrenaline junkies hooked on helping Harry.  Harry could duel without thinking much. He did not overthink the process, which was admirable. In the Little Hangletone graveyard, while Cedric Diggory wondered where they had landed the second Harry and Ced took the Quidditch Cup for theirs for the win. Harry told Cedric to grab the portkey and scat (see, Harry didn’t mind if that portray wasn’t there for him and he didn’t know how to disapparate, so Harry would die or think up another brilliant way out of Voldemort’s resurrection scene). And then Harry faced Voldemort and dueled him. He didn’t over think it.   Harry didn’t have an awe for Voldemort or really any other adult, except for Dumbledore and Sirius. So Harry, having grown up in a decidedly unmagical world, had little fear, and he thought on his feet. Had too. To Survive. If Harry thought it through the way many of us would, he’d be shaking in his trainers and would be unable to properly hold his wand to produce any satisfactory sort of magic. So Harry lived in the moment, as much as he could.  Sure, Harry Potter felt scared about his death. But, he didn’t dwell on it. Somewhere, in his future a very dark wizard would face off against him, so he tucked that day away, and lived at Hogwarts quite happily. Harry was the one who saw Peter Pettigrew on the Marauder’s Map, and as confused as Harry and friends were about Peter being alive, they went into the Whomping Willow, and Harry knocked out Snape, just long enough to hear Sirius and Lupin out. Most students wouldn’t give their professors a concussion (and that’s a good thing), but Harry doesn’t think that way. The consequences come later. Right now, problems in front of him need addressing, and why not him? That’s how Harry thinks!  That’s why I love Harry Potter! He’s brave, too brave for his own good. He enters “adult” situations without thinking he’s out of his league. Because Harry’s not. He notices nuances that others fail to see. And the kid just reacts. And he reacts in a way that works. Could it be the Horcrux in him? Maybe. Voldemort’s soul might give Harry that push. All I know is Harry is fun to watch. He possesses so much chutzpah!  See? No Quidditch necessary! Harry is pretty good at a lot more than a game of Quidditch. And even there, his fast thinking and quick reflexes serve him well.

As a wizard (versus a Quidditch player), what was Harry Potter best at? Defence Against the Dark Arts. Harry is the best at Defensive magic and the best duelist in his year, and in other years too—he was better than most of the students at Hogwarts. He was good enough to be the real Defence teacher in fifth year (thanks to Hermione setting it all up for him)—Umbridge was as much of a Fraud as Lockhart in her own way—and some of the students he was teaching were in sixth and seventh year. But Harry is more than the best at defence and the best duelist among Hogwarts students. He led a team in battle against adult wizards in the Department of Mysteries and despite taking a lot of damage, they held their own long enough for the Order to get there and finish the job. That battle between Harry’s team and the Death Eaters must have been going on for a while, because after the Order arrived, things were wrapped up fairly quickly and when it was all over, it was about 4:30 am (when Harry was portkeyed back to Hogwarts, dawn was breaking, which in Scotland is roughly 4:30 am at that time of year). And by the end of Deathly Hallows, at 17 years old, Harry had grown skillful enough to take on most adult wizards—including Voldemort.  Also worth noting is that Harry was the second most magically powerful wizard in the books. Dumbledore was ostensibly the first most powerful wizard, and Voldemort came in third. (magical power should not be conflated with skill, experience, or knowledge—magical power is raw physical power and strength of Willpower). In third year—at thirteen years old—Harry produced a Patronus as powerful as Dumbledore’s (and no, that wasn’t a fluke—time travel did not confer power on Harry. That power was already in Harry. The time travel just revealed that he was capable of wielding such power). In fourth year—when he was fourteen—he was already more powerful magically than Voldemort. He kicked Voldemort’s ass during the Twin-Core duel. … Harry forced Voldemort’s wand to submit—if Voldemort was more powerful, he would have forced Harry’s wand to submit. GoF Ch 34: He [Harry] concentrated every last particle of his mind upon forcing the bead back towards Voldemort, his ears full of Phoenix Song, his eyes furious, fixed… and slowly, very slowly, the beads quivered to a halt, and then, just as slowly, they began to move the other way… and it was Voldemort’s wand that was vibrating extra-hard now… Voldemort who looked astonished and almost fearful… One of the beads of light was quivering, inches from the tip of Voldemort’s wand. Harry didn’t understand why he was doing it, didn’t know what it might achieve… but he now concentrated as he had never done in his life on forcing that bead of light right back into Voldemort’s wand… and slowly… very slowly… it moved along the golden thread… it trembled for a moment… and then it connected… At once, Voldemort’s wand began to emit echoing screams of pain… then—Voldemort’s red eyes widened with shock…

We are clearly told he was at the top of his DADA class, and because he was in a fight for his life, he did not skimp in that class. This is all the more amazing considering the uneven teaching he had. Over six years, he had three good teachers of DADA (Lupin, Moody, Snape) and one of those three was an imposter, and of his remaining teachers, one was actually his greatest enemy (Quirrell), one was a fraud (Lockhart), and the other was a political fanatic sent to undermine the subject (Umbridge). In fact, Umbridge was so bad that Harry had to secretly teach the class that year. His three best spells seem to have been Expelliarmus, Accio, and Expecto Patronum. However, he did have a lot of other spells under his belt. But he learned both Accio and Expecto Patronum well ahead of his peers, and the latter even before many adults; his Patronus was particularly strong. And of course, Expelliarmus is how he defeated Voldemort. Harry was a powerful young wizard, but I think that the biggest advantage he had in learning defense were his clear motives: first, he was fighting to survive, and second, he was fighting to protect others. He had other motives as well, but I do not believe that he would have fought nearly so hard for revenge alone.

Expelliarmus. That’s it. Just kidding. Harry Potter was exceptionally skilled at Defense Against Dark Arts. He was skilled in defensive skills and understood a lot of the power required to perform the skills well. He was able to perform the Patronus Charm at 13 years of age, something that Lupin states is remarkable. He is really talented at expelliarmus, a skill that he hones and understands the power of in a battle. He evenly matches three other 17 year old wizards at age 14 and through common sense and luck, manages to come out the victor. He is self-sacrificing and this allows him to abandon some fear when he faces situations that should end in death. He (and Dumbledore) go up against dozens of Inferi and Harry manages to bring Dumbledore back, mostly safely. I don’t necessarily believe that DADA was what he was best at, but where the skills that he developed shone through the best. Harry was best at caring for others and doing all that he could to protect them. He worked with many other witches and wizards but in the end, it was his desire to protect those he loved that gave him the power to succeed in dangerous situations.

Harry’s best subject was undeniably Defence against the dark arts, that was after all the subject he achieved an Outstanding on (beating even Hermione, who was the brightest witch of her age, with her only achieving Exceeds Expectations). Two of the best things Harry was good at were casting the patronus charm in his third year (a spell that is beyond O.W.L and even N.E.W.T ability level magic) but also his duelling skills (Harry is possibly the greatest dueller of his generation), I mean he’s defeated Voldemort, the greatest dark wizard of all time. Not to mention that he basically taught DADA to Hogwarts students for an entire year, that takes some skills to lead and teach. Harry shon on the Quidditch pitch as seeker and later as captain of the Gryffindor quidditch team. He must’ve been pretty talented to be the youngest player in a century. There’s no denying that Harry is an incredibly talented wizard to quote Hermione: “you’re a brilliant wizard Harry”.

Thinking on his feet, lamenting his fate (Oh woe is me! - Blergh, get over it! You will never fade into the background, Potter, so use that fame for something good, damned!) and being mediocre/wasting potential (he had potential, he mastered the patronus early - but sadly he never used it wisely! Slacking of with (Mo-)Ron to play (and lose!) chess was more important, as was signing up for useless electives…seriously, Harry is a dumbass and IMHO should have died for his stupidity…the message of the books is: You maybe a dumbass slacker, as long as you are willing to take a bulled (well: Curse) for your friends…which is a shockingly bad message IMHO!)

He was much much MUCH better at Quidditch than he was a wizard. At best, Harry was good at a couple of spells, but that doesn’t make someone a great wizard. He was really fantastic as a Seeker which was put on display and hinted at throughout all 7 books, but not really in the movies unfortunately. I firmly believe that anybody who scrutinizes the books will believe as I do, but if you only watched the movies, I can completely understand your question.
Expelliarmus, and the Patronus charm. He wasn’t much good at anything else.

Defence. He was highly skilled. Corporal Patronise at 13 O in OWL Held his own against a Basilisk, a Werewolf, death eaters, Voldy etc etc Taught a class successfully including Neville who thrives in DA

I would say that he was very talented with both a broomstick and wand. If you read the books you would know that he was able to teach all of Dumbledore's Army lots of different spells, spells that he already mastered at least a year ago.

As a wizard (versus a Quidditch player), what was Harry Potter best at? The Disarming Charm (Expelliarmus) He also managed to successfully cast a fully corporeal Patronus Charm(Expecto Patronum) at the age of 13, which is impressive.

As a wizard, Harry was truly great. After all, while still a teenager, Harry defeated the most powerful dark wizard of all time. Something even Dumbledore was unable to achieve. Admittedly, Harry was a great Seeker in Quidditch. But he really wasn’t in Hogwarts to play Quidditch was he?
Honestly, Quidditch. He was a natural at flying, while at his school subjects he did not display an inner talent for any of them. You’re welcome to disagree.

I don’t think this a good comparison. Harry Potter was a wizard and did arguably quiet well in magic school - he later got one of the most difficult jobs in the wizarding world, so yep he was quiet good wizard but still Quidditch was his hobby and he was a natural flyer his talent was even recognized by a professional Quidditch player (Krum).
He was best at the Patronus and Disarming spells. He only used Expelliarmus against Voldemort, even in their battle at the end of the Deathly Hallows pt. 2.

Thanks for the A2A. Personally I think Harry was a better quidditich player. He was talented. But when it came to wizardry he had his friends to help him. Ron and Hermione made Harry who he was. He was a better human than a wizard. His courage and bravery made him a good wizard but his skills made him a better player.
Hmmmm let’s seeeeeee how about killing Voldemort
